div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: EXPRESS SERVICE FROM NOVEMBER, 1st, UNTIL FURTHER NOTICE.

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. From Nov. 1st sleeping and dining cars on Egyptian State Railways are attached to ordinary trains from Cairo on Mon.; Wed. and Sat. at 3 p.m. and from Luxor on Tues, Thurs, and Sun. at 5.30 p.m.- From 2nd Dec. Luxe trains with sleeping and dining Cars will run on same day leaving Cairo and Luxor at 6.30 p.m. Early in Janurary these trains will be run daily. Express between Shallal and Halfa carry mails and 1st class passengers only, but 2nd class passengers may be accepted if accomodation is available. Express steamers do not stop at any stations on either up or down journeys between Shallal and Halfa. To insure accomadation official passengers must have warrant stamped "accommodation Available" by Sudan Agent, Cairo, or Civil Secretary, Khartoun. A specially fitted barge with 1st and 2nd class accomodation for native ladies will be attached to these steamer. There will be a restaurant on thee mail steamers.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.p: The Mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and O.) will be distributed at the Alexandria Post Office at 5 o'clock this evening.

div.head: Savoy Palace Hotel.
div.p: A children's dance and Christmas tree will be given at the Savoy Palace Hotel by the French Community of Alexandria on the 22nd inst. from 4 to 7 p.m.

div.head: New Year's Calendars. Messrs.
div.p: Whitehead Morris & Co., the manufacting and export stationers and printers, of Alexandria and Cairo, are issuing some useful calendars and almanacs for the New Year to their numerous clients.

div.head: Sakhara Funds.
div.p: The German exploration party now working Sakhara have recently been discovering some new tombs, though, as yet none of any first-rate importance, and there seem to be indications that the site of an ancient temple may soon be uncovered.

div.head: Y.W.C A, Salo of Work
div.p: We regret that we are compelled to hold over our correspondent's account of the Young Women's Christian Association's Sale of Work at Cairo until to-morrow. The copy we bave in hand far exceeds the space at our disposa. and much is necessarily held over from day 'to day.

div.head: The 'Egyptian Punoh."
div.p: We have received a copy of the first number of the "Egyptian Punch," and we confess to disappointment at finding that the coloured cartoon, which, from'the name of the journal, we had been led to expect would be at least amusing, is simply nauseous, while both the drawing and colouring are of very poor order.

div.head: Rlbero's Cloud
div.p: This circus situated at the foot of the Rue de l'ancienne Bourse continues to attract large audiences. In the new programme a rather sensational bicycle performance is presented, termed "La Piste de la mort" and is certainly *very well executed. There is to be a matinée on Thursday at 4.0 p.m. The entertainment is well worth a visit. i

div.head: British Men-of-War.
div.p: We understand that H. M. 8. "Diana," which, arrived here on Sunday will remain in Egyptian waters for some time, probably until the end, of February. The "Dreadnought" is supposed to be dug here on Friday and we are also to have a visit shortly from the "Implac. able". The Dreadnought", our informant tells us, is to remain here for the opening of the Boghoe Pass.

div.head: The Cum sonson.
div.p: The gum season has commenced at Dueim. The profits realized by the gam merchants doring the last season seem to have encouraged them to start buying at high figures this year. Sales have been effected at about 80 P.T. per kantar, which is very high for the opening of the season. Nothing definite has been known as yet as to the quantity or quality of the product this year,and the prices will no doubt fluctuate considerably

div.head: INTERESTING BANKING APPOINTMENT.
div.p: As reported by my telegram of to day Mr. Raoul Hector Foà, of Messrs. King and Foà, has been appointed a director of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank (Limited). The appointment is in many respects an interesting one. Mr. Foa's fatherMr. Octave Foa--was for many years (from 1864 to 1881) the secretary and manager of the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, and was elected a director of that institution in 1881. The "Standard" remarks that this is the first instance of a partner in a private discount firm occupying at the same time a position on the directorate of a bank.

div.head: NEW CAIRO MUSICAL SOCIETY.
div.p: We have much pleasure in announcing the inauguration of the series of concerts, which the new Société des Concerts da Caire has undertaken to give during the whole of the present season. The first concert, which took place last Sunday,was in every way satisfactory. The Society was ' very happily inspired in choosing the concert room of the Semiramis hotel, which meets very requirement. The orchestra, which belongs to the Khedivial Opera Coinpany, executed with great skill and feeling the various pieces, which the committee had chosen with great taste and care. We must specially mention the execution of Mozart's Jupiter symphony, and Wagner's "Siegfrid," the delicate and intricate harmonies of which the orchestra interpreted with no little art. Mme Magne, of the Khedivial opera house, also song three charming songs, especially distinguishing herself in the last one, Schu. maon's "La Fiancée," which was really splendid. ly rendered. "We noticed Lady Gorst, Lady Valda Machell, Count and Countess de Se
rionne, "Count A. de Zogheb, Mrs. Hunter, M. " de Valdrôme, Mr. A. Suares and many others.

div.head:
A CAIRO "CAUSE CELEBRE"
THE VIVIAN AFFAIR.
div.p: A decree nisi has been granted by the Divorce Division on the petition of Lord Vivian, who sought for a dissolution of his marriage with Lady Vivian on the ground of adultery. Mr Alfred Curphey, the well-known AngloEgyptian financier, was the correspondent.

Lady Vivian was one of the belles of the last Cairo season and made a prolonged stay at the Savoy Hotel. She is the daughter of the late Mr. William A. Fanning and was married to Lord Vivian in 1903. There is one daughter and one son by the marriage.

Mr. Alfred Curphey arrived at Alexandria last Wednesday by the S.S "Heliopolis" and after a brief visit to Cairo returned to Europe by the same steamer last Saturday. He is one of the directors of the Egyptian Mail Steamship Company and bas considerable financial interests in this country.

div.head: WATER COLOUR EXHIBITION. A FAMOUS ARTIST.
div.p: Many Alexandrian residents, and not a few of our étrangers en passage visited yesterday the exhibition of water colour drawings, which are being displayed at the Savoy Palace Hotel by Mr X 0. Lamplough, whose name is now placed in the first rank of our present day artists : to this we must add that others, who were unable to visit the exhibition yesterday or were unaware that it was being held, can do so any morning or afternoon up to Monday next.

As regards Mr. Lamplougb's talent as an artist, we can add nothing to what we have written in former years. On his first visit to Egypt we recognised his genius and did not hesitate to express our opinion that a great future was before him. That our opinion has been fully justified is proved by the success which he has gained and by the general admiration which his paintings have evoked. Few men have spanned the bridge of fame in so short a time, and we doubt that any younger artist has ever been commanded to exhibit his pictures in private to our Sovereign. Mr. Lamplough has, moreover, gained the patronage of many other members of the Royal family, besides other distinguished persons, whose names are well-known to Franco-Egyptiang.

of the present exhibition it is only possible to say that each picture has its individual merits; to criticise them is beyond our power, for on each we can but bestow unstinted and absolutely genuine praise. We can but mention our favourities, and these of course must depend opon personal choice. One of the first | pictures which attracted our attention was a most delicately coloured painting of "Doomed Philae," a replica of one of the two pictures purchased by King Edward, though we are | almost inclined to note a wonderfully nature

like painting of the Citadel at Cairo from Ghezireh as our first favourite. "The first gleam of sunlight o'er river and bill," as the artist entitles one of his pictures, is full of warmth and richness of colouring. The painting of the tombs of the Mamelukes with the Pyramids in the far distance gives especial prominence to that vast variety of colouring for which Egyptian scenery is famous ; and, again, Mr. Lamplough has been faithful to the point of perfection in his painting of "Mist effect near Kous." In the foreground is a stretch of sand dunes, clear and well-defined and growing gradually more and more indistinct, clusters of prickly pears are toned down below their full richness of green, while behind rises a group of date-palms, their trunks most cleverly hidden by mist, while their graceful, fronded tops rise sharply above the dimming, moisture-soaked atmosphere to boldly face the world, oblivious to the very humidity which gives them life. Other pictures which we must put forward | as among our favourites are "An afterglow near Tel el Kebir," "An afterglow in the desert," "Sheikh's tomb near Matarieh," "On the Nile banks at Aşkonan," "Sunrise at Bardis," and "On the Nile near Cairo."

div.head: "UNION ARTISTIQUE FRANCAISE."
div.p: The energetic members of this society presented for the amusement of their members and friends on Saturday last Edmond Rostand's three act comedy "Les Romanesques" and they are to be heartily congratulated on the unqualified success of the entertainment. A large and fashionable gathering assembled to witness the performance, among whom we noticed the | French Consul, Mons. P. Girard. The play was prettily staged and each character was well supported. Mlle Sequier made a charming Sylvette and M. J. Ruben proved himself equal to all that was required in the lovemaking scenes, which, for an amateur, is saying a good deal. As Straforel, Mons. Paul Levy I gave us, as he invariably does, an excellent impersonation of the character, and in the difficult scene in the third act with Sylvette excelled himselt. The rather trying character of Bergamin was exceedingly well played by Mr. A. Paul who is also to be complimented on the excellence of his make-up. The smaller characters were also well sustained by Messrs. H. Lanmon and G. Lusena.
PARIS-HOUSE GENEVA: Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her models at the Hotel Villa Victoria, Cairo.

div.head: ANOTHER COTTON CRISIS
LOCK-OUT IN PROSPECT.
MASTERS STAND FIRM.
div.p: Another cotton crisis is threatened as the result of yesterday's mass meeting of the masters, which was of a warlike nature and seriously threatened that if two mills, at present closed by a strike, are not working shortly the whole trade will stop. The masters intend to act as one man against the anjust demands of the work-people in the ring as regards spinners' wages. In the meantimo business is being conducted under strike clauses, which hamper international trade. The Board of Trade is watching affairs closely. Mr. Lloyd George will attend the meeting at Manchester if necessary.

div.head: PUBLIC HEALTH DEPARTMENT. CAIRO SEWAGE.
div.p: A committee formed of the following members, Mr. Carkeet James, Mr. P. Graham, and Mr. Roccasera has been appointed, and will sit immediately to consider the advisability of the decreos relating to the aewerage of Cairo which came before the Court of Appeal for deliberation in May 1898 and in January 1899, being presented to the Council of Ministers for consideration in its present form. We understand that these decrees deal with the localities in which the new system of sewers are to be laid. and also the quarters in the town where work will be first commenced.

It is probable that the construction work will not be commenced before the beginning of the year 1909 at the earliest, as detailed plads dealing with all districts concerned will have to be prepared and this preliminary work will occupy a considerable time, as there are many questions which will have to be very carefully considered before the actual constructional work is begun, also until the main sewers are laid, and the pumping installation and the sewage farm are completed, it is highly improbable that any houses or buildings can be connected with the system of sewers, so that for some considerable time things will remain practically as they are now. :

We understand that the report of the Controller General is now before the Adviser, and that it will be submitted for the consideration of the Council of Ministers early in the coming year. It is probable that in the native quarters where buildings of the nature of "Robeshes" are met with, special sanitary conditions will be introduced for their drainage and water supply.

On consideration of the question from various points of view it ooours to us that many of the distriota which at present laok a sufficient water supply should be the first consideration of the authorities, and now that the water scheme is pratically approved of, there is no reason why the Caire Water Company should not at once proceed to remedy this state of affairs.

We earnestly trust that the finding of the commission above mentioned will favoar the immediate consideration of the previons de crees. The question is one of much importance to the whole towr, and if the decree: formerly prepared after much deliberation can be made of use now, much time will be saved, to the advantage of all.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: . The trial of Thomas Cannon for the mnrder of Charles King did not conolude until vester day evening. The accused was found guilty of murder, but no sentence was passed.

div.head: DR. RUFFER'S APPOINTMENT.
div.p: Dr. Ruffer President of the quarantine Board of Egypt, who has made some valuable contributions to the discussiong of the International Hygiene Conference now in sessionhere, has been appointed a member of the Committee charged with drafting regulations for the establishment in Paris of an International Bureau of Hygiene.

The delegates of France proposed that the ex per.ses of the Bureau should not exceed £6,000 yearly. The Italian representatives, however, soggested £8,000 and Learly all the other delegates, including those of Frauce, were ready to accept the suggestion, but Dr. Thomson (Eng. land) insisted that the sum should be limited to £6,000. He was supported by Sir Benjamin Franklyn, representative of India, and alti mately carried the point.

It was also arranged that each country should choose to which of six specified categories it wished to belong, paying a quota accordingly, and having a proportionate number of votes. Great Britain and India chose the first category, and are entitled to six votes each. Ibrahina Pisha Neghib declared that Egypt chose the fourth category, which entitles her to three dotes.

div.head:
TURKEY'S TROUBLES
MACEDONIA AND THE POWERS.
div.p: The "Daily Telegraph's" Constantinople correspondent announces that the Ambassadors of the Powers have handed a collective Note to the Sultan on the subject of Macedonia. The Note contains demands for the renewal of the Porta's agreements for another seven years in regard to the appointments of Civil Agents, Gendarmerie Officers and Financial Agents in Macedonia.

div.head: DEATH OF A PRINCE. IBRAHIM PASHA PAZEL.
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Prince Ibrahim Pasha Pazel, son of the late Prince Moustapha Pasha Fadel, at the age of 45 years
The funeral took place yesterday morning and was attended by the Princes of the Khedivial family and Abmed Zakhy Pasha, Grand Master of Ceremonies to the Khedive.

div.head: CAIRO ESTATES COMPANY.
div.p: The Cairo Estates Company is to be voluntarily wound up soon and the capital retunded to the shareholders. The capital of this comDADY was LE. 400.000 in 100.000 ordinary £1 shares. The public were asked to subscribe for 50,000 sbares and the publio subscription was opened on the 26th March last. The original directors were Messrs. Greville Palmer, Montagu Summers, George Nungovich Bey, Alfred Carphey and Maitre Carton de Wiart. According to the prospectus the capital had been subscribed as follows : Egyptian Estates, 50,000 shares, Mr. Montagu. div.head: ALEXANDRIA CONSERVATOIRE.
div.p: We published a report in Monday's issue of the concert on Saturday night at the Alexandria Conservatoire, but the following account from another point of view will be of interest: -

The coup d'oeil from the gallery opposite the stage was charming and the troop of young men, maidons and children, so nicely dressed as they stood on the stage for the opening chorus made a most satisfactory impression on the audience. After five years' steady work onder their capable and hard-working profeg. nors the progress made is very creditable and those who have been interesting themselves in this institution from the beginning can bear witness to the rapid development made by the pupils of the Alexandria Conservatoire. All nationalities are represented in the classes, but those pupils who were best fitted to take part in the evening's programóne as soloists were drawn from the Italian, Greek and' Armenian communities. The opening chorus was wellrendered and went with a steady swing, responding with precision to Signor Galletti's båton and showing a greatly improved discipline since they first came under his direction.

This was followed by a trio of Haydn's which was played by three Armenian popils. Messrs. Tirighinan E. and J. Papasian, The third item was a violin solo played by a small boy of seven, M. Cantom, a papil of Signor Lama who played his piece from the famous Barber of Seville with astonishing precision and tunefulness and did not seem in the least abashed by the sea of faces below him. The song by Meyerbeer given by a Greek pupil was one of the numbers most appreciated on the programme. Mr. Lambrides should have a future before him if he continues studying with the same reserve and refinement as be showed in his performance last night and he does infinite credit to the good teaching of Signor Galletti.

Another Greek pupil, Sig. Perdichidis, delighted his hearers by his rendering of an extremely sympathetic piece by E. Papasiad (another popil) which was followed by Raff's famous Cavatina. Mr. Lambridis is an example of a pupil absolutely created by the Alexandria Conservatoire and he has been trained from the very begining by Prof. Lama. The first part was brought to a close by a brilliant performance of a favourite Schezzo of Mendelssohn by a girl of 14, Signa. Carasao.

Part 2 opened with another chorus in which Sign. Azzarelli took the soprano solo. She is very promising but the voice is still in its earlier stage and we hope she will not overstrajn her voice whilst her throat and constitution are yet unequal to any great effort. We were glad to hear Sig. R. Scinica again, who has made distinct progress, but we should prefer to hear him in less ambiticus and more sympathetic pieces another time. A duet by Schumann came next by "Sigra. Mangeri and Sig. Papanti, an Aria by Lindner for the violoncello given carefully by Sig. J. Papasian and an Andantino by Chopin was played by another member of the Cantoni fainily on the oboe-class lately formed and under the guidance of Prof. Onesti. A chorus by Bach"Sanctus," a fugue in 4 parts, was admirably rendered by the whole of the vocal strength of the Conservatoire and brought a most interest. ing concert to an end. We cannot close this critique without saying a word about the Director, Maestro Colella, who being still in deep mouming took no part in the proceedings, but to whom is due all praise for the creatiou and organisation of this Alexandria Soboot of music, which is doing him so much credit:

div.head:
THE ESNEH BARRAGE.
EGYPTS MODERN MASONRY.
div.p: It is only when one realizes the hundreds of men working upon them, the thousands of tons of material need in building them, the energies and years that are spent in their completion, that one begins to wonder if the modern barrage of Egypt will ever rank among the hoary monuments of the future as have the pyramids of the past: or whether they too will one day pasg into nothingness like so many of the other great works of the country

A visit to Esneh at the present moment will make one think of many things; but it is almost impossible to watch the scenes of activity, round the construction of the mammoth weir, without being reminded of similar scenes in byėgone ages, when Egyptian kings were engaged in raising monumental works either for the good of the land or to their own | glory. To-day there are the samé gangs of busy workers swarming over the scene : only instead of slave labour groaning under a cruel joke they are free men working for fair and honest wage and protected by many a modern institation. The ingenuity of the times has naturally supplied many labour saving contrivances unheard of in the past ; but the Egyptian setting and the Egyptian type is still the same, and where the modern workman is left to his own devices he will use the same methods as did his far away ancestors. The very stone used in the building of the present dam reminds one of the past. There are the huge blocks of granite brought from Assouan as of yore, and Gebel Sillah is still supplying vast quantities of the same material which centuries ago was being brought down river to build the palaces and temples of Thebes and Karnak.

The sleepy native town of Esneh with its temple and other, antiquities lies upon the western bank of the river': the bustle and clamour of the barrage works is confined for the most part to the eastern bank where all is desert if not desolation between the railway station and the river. bank. Desolation of a Bort: for enormous heaps of stone, brick yards and other unlovely sights cumber the ground, while the throb of machinery and the paffing and screaming ofengines fill the air with their clamour. There close to the river has arisen the little settlement which is the head quar ters for all who have to do with the work There is the busy station yard where trucks of sto ne are continually being unladen : there are offices and stores; and there too the bungalows which have grown to be the homes of the European workers, Bungalows of white 'with green shutters and verandahs for the goverment official,. one storied bungalows yellow. washed, for those in the employ of John Aird and Co. And in spite of arid desertand other disadvantages, these bungalows have grown into very comfortable homes ; their wide verandabs mostly sbaded with luxuriant creepers, lootab plants, convolvulus ; while their patches of I garden are bright with carefully tended flowers, marigolds, sunflowers thriving apace in the sandy, soil.

A few minutes walk across the intervening hummocks and one is in the midst of a scene of ceaseless activity. The steep banks swarm with myriads of blue garbed workmen, endless streams of snarling camels block the way. One side a great angainly mud-dredger is cattingite way through a narrow canal, on the other the great slope of masonry supports one end of the daily growing dam which ere long will lie athwart the stream. It is good to stand there for a few minutes and watch that swarm of human bees, each doing his very best in his ·

seeming futile way, and the great edifice Tgrowing, growing as certainly as the comb I within the hive.Watch, too, that fleet of barges tethered side by side from the bank into the stream, from which tons and tons of earth are being hurled overboard into the water. Much sooner than one thinks that earth will form a sud that tops the surface and makes a solid bank round a portion of the river bed, when the water enclosed can be puinped away and buildmg operations may be begun. Great floors of
cement and concrete pitched on either side I with walls of lime-stone, will give foundation

for massive piers and abutmente, so that | when the waters flow back once more the masonery is ready to be continued above its aur. face. On the western bank there is more to see. Already the lock walls are completed with the loug Alights of steps leading to the road. way. Already many of the piers have reached their full height ; and before the next rise of the river they must all be well above the flood. When that time comes the worst of the work will be over and the three-quarters of a mile I width of river will be studded by its row of

piers. Even then there will remain many months of ardaous labour, to be done on piers, abutments, superstructure, fitting the powerful sluices in their sockets eto, eto, before the Esneh barrage is ready to do its good work in storing the flood and spreading fertilisation far and wide across the valley.

Bat when one thinks that it is less than two yesirs ago that the first preparations were made, that the actual building operations only commenced last March, one can will believe that the finishing touches will be given at no very distant date. Refetence has already been made to the institutions for the protection of the modern workman, and chief among these at Esneh is the hospital which has been erected by John Aird and Co. on the western bank of the river between the town and the barrage works. A well laid out and shady garden ser rounds the various warda, ench with a wide verándah and most comfortable aspect. There are wards for English and Italians as well as for the natives, and an isolation ward for fever

ases. There is also a very complete operating theatre, for as may be imagined most of the cases treated are the results of accidente.. An English doctor is in residence here with a . staff of male nurses, and many an Eoglish cot. age hospital is not so well equipped and arranged as this little one on the banks of the river Nile.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The Duke of Brunswick has left Cairo for a trip to Upper' Egypt.
Prince d'Arenberg, Chairman of the Board of the Suez Canal. Co. and M. Lepine, Prefect of the Parisian Police and also a director of the Canal Co. are due at Port Said from France on Friday next.
- Sir Rudolph Slatin Pasha is expected back at. Khartoom towards the end of the present month from his trip to the Eastern Sudan.
Lord Eustace Cecil and Mrs. Cecil have returned to Egypt from Khartonn.
Laura Lady Grant will sail from Marseilles on the 20th for Cairo, where she will spend the winter. Lady Grant has let her house in Estonsquare to General Lyttelton till Easter.
Sir Thomas Liptop is dee at Alexandria on Christmas Eve by the 8.8. "Heliopolis" and will stay at the Savoy Palace Hotel, where ba will remain several days before proceeding to Cairo.
Mrs. Holland, of Benhali Indgo, Saxmandham, who has been staying at Cannes, has left for Egypt She is accompanied by her son, her sister, Miss Rygate, and Mias Louise Vanneck.
Lady Blomfield'ia rəlinguishing her post a Vice-President of the Alexandria Conservatoire of Music at the end of this year.
Lady Blomfield's brother-in-law, Vice-Admira Sir Richard Poore, Bart. C.vo., has been appointed to be Commander in Chief of the Australian Station and hoista his flag in March next.
M. Camille Saint-Saëns, the great Prench Composer, who arrived at Port Said from Barcelona, is staying at Cairo.L
The latest Arrivals at the Grand Hotel, Khartoum, included :

Mr. Chev. Carlo Rosetti, Mr. Engène Hirsch, Mr. Topolian, Mr. Gillmann, Mr. O.J. Osborne, Mr. U. Benincamps, Mr. Smith Bills, Mr. Shennany Bey, Mr. W. H. Home, Mr. H. Matheus, J. G. Jabt, Mr. Gobbetis, Mr. Garnet Jorta, Mr. Santo Garibaldi, Mr. Wathings, Mr. Car. penter, Mr. Pizzagali, Dr Bertorelli.

The Duchess of Aosta (travelling under the name of Contessa della Cisterna) has arrived at the Cataract Hotel bere and will stay a few days with her party before going up to Khar toum where she hopes to enjoy some big game hunting.

Other visitors at the Cataract are Prince and Princess A. Licven with their family froin Russia, the Hon. Edith Gibba and party, the Hon. Mr. Overend, Colonel B. Allen, General and Mr. Thorneycroft, Miss Crozier, Mr. and Mrs.. Walter Ahlquist of Helsingfors and Mr: and Mrs. A. Solvay, who are on their way to some lion hunting in the Sudan.
The Dukes and Duchess of Devonshiro are living on their dahabeah "Serapis" moored by Elephantine Island
There will be many visitors at Assouan' for Christmas, some of whom are expected by Cook's beautiful new steame the "Egypt," which is due at Luxor on the 16th.
Asaonan has an English church and the Christmas services will induce many people going further soath, to break their journey and spend the great festival here.

div.head:
England, France, and Germany.
The Moroccan Question

div.p: With regard to the persistent rumour that the Emperor and King Edward had decided to charge France with the entire responsibility of maintaining order in Morocco, it is stated here in official circles that during his Majesty's recent visit to Englad political questions were not discussed and the Moroccan question particularly has not been negociated either between the two Monarchs or governments. (Beuter)

div.head:
Sultan's Jewels In Pawn.
MONT DE PIETE GIVES 1,250,000 FRS.

div.p: The Mont de Piete has lent 1,250,000 francs on Sultan Abd el Aziz's jewels. (haves)
The state Pawnbroking Administration has advanced 1,250,000 francs on the sultan of morocco's jewels. (reuter)

div.head:
The Secret Consistory
Denouncement of Modernists.

div.p: At the consistory the Pope deplored the attacks on the Church even by those who should safeguard it. He especially referred to the Italian pages in this connection. He denounced the Modernists. (Reuter)
The cotton EMployers Federation has decided on a general lockout unless the Ring Spinners' strikes at Oldham are settled within a reasonable time. (Reuter)
A colliery explosion has occurred at Birmingham (Alabama). 35 bodies have been recovered. 70 persons have perished. This is the third terrible disaster within a fortnight. (Reuter)

Mulay Hafid has played his last card in the unsuccessful attempt to retake Mazagan. The important Seragna tribe and others have abandoned Mulay Hafid and proclaimed Abd-el-Aziz and joined the latter's forces. Mulay Hafid is practically beleagured in Marrakesh. (Reuter)
The Branlieres column has reached Cheraa and advanced as far as Mouluya. (Havas)
Fifty Redical journalists and 100 typographers have been arrested on account of a revolutionary organisation. (Havas)
In consequence of the students' agitation the University will close its doors. (Havas)
The Government has decided to close the University for two months on account of the students' resistance of compulsory gymnastics. (Reuter)

div.head:
Austria And Hungary.
Dissension in the Reichsrath.

div.p: The Premier described the resolution passed in the Reichsrath, calling on Hungary to deal justly with her various nationalities, as an affront for which she must receive satisfaction. (Reuter)
Reicharath, The Premier said that the government declined to carry out the resolution passed in the Reicharath. He begged the House to abstain from meddling with Hungarian affairs. (Reuter)
Lord Kelvin is sinking slowly. (later) Lord Kelvin is dead. (Reuter)

The "Times" learns from Teheran that the release of the Premier, who is a holder of a high British order, was due to the solicitation of the British Legation. In view of the seriousness of the news from Percia Great Britain and Russia are co-operating in taking steps to relieve the situation. (Reuter)

There are indications that the Californians intend to utilize the arrival of the battleships for the purpose of strengthening the anit- oriental agitation, and are organizing great demonstrations in honour of the fleet. (Reuter)

div.head: Khedivial Mail Steamship Co.
div.p: The annual meeting of the Khedivial Mail Steamship and Graving Dock Company (Limited) was held on the 9th inst. at Wineheater House, Mr. Charles A. Hanson-presided.
The notice convening the meeting having been read by the secretary (Mr. L Holiday) the report and accounts (which have already appeared in the "Shipping Gazette,") were taken as read.

The Chairman: I am sure you will all join me in greatly regretting the absence from our meeting to-day, through severe and protracted illness, of our most capable and distinguished chairman, Sir Anchlaud Colvin, and I have no doubt it will be your wish that I should convey to him an expression of your sincere sympathy and of our best wishes for his early and complete recovery. The year which ended on June 30 last was, I am glad to say on the whole a satisfactory year. In comparison with 1905-1906 the traffic earnings have shown increases from almost every service worked by the company. and from almost every source of revenue which has been available to the company. The only rexceptions which I think can be made to this general rule and the earnings from the Suez factory, from the floating dock at Alexandria, and from the revenue derived from the international mail service. In these items there have been decreases but, the decreases are trifling and of no serious importance.
The Pilgrim Traffic

In analysing the accounts for the year we find that the lagest increase of revenue has come to us from the pilgrim trade, which last year luckily happened to be exceptionally good. The pilgrim trade, as you are probably aware, is an omportant branch of our service, and is an important source of revenue, but in this, as in all other departments of trade and traffic, there are good years and bad years, and sometimes it may happen that our carrying power is taxed to its utmost capacity with large earnings, while at other times our tonnage may be largely in excess of the requirements with coreesponginly small earnings, This pilgrim trade is, however, an extremely onerous trade, as we are obliged to provide for every emergency and to make our organisation and service as perfect as possible to satisf the exacting requirements of the Government of Egypt, and to secure for the satifation of the pilgrims themselves that they are carried with safety and comfort.

div.head: Devidend
div.p: The net Restrit of the whole year is that, notwithstanding our increased expenditure both for ordinary account and special repairs to ships, and leaving also provided an additional fund for extraordinary depreciation, we are still able to recommend to you the declaration of a dividend at the rate of 10 per cent. per annum, and to carry forward to the next year's accounts a trifle over 13,000l. I hope you will consider this on the whole a not unsatifactory record.
New Capital

Referring again to the report, I may perhaps be permitted to refer to the paragraph wich relates to the issue of new capital. You will recollect that a year ago the directors asked you for additional capital powers, and you very generously accessed to our request. At that time two facts were prominent in our minds, viz : First, the necessity for building two or three new first class steamers. Secondly, the necessity of finding the funds for building these vessels, and for other capital purposes, by an issue of new capital. At that time the financial sky was comparatively unclouded. The financial condition of Egypt particularly appeared to be eminently satisfactory, and we were assured and had reason to believe that Egypt was eager to join with London in finding this capital at an appreciable premium upon its par value, and at such a premium as would be satisfactoru to the directors: and there is no doubt, indeed, that had we been in a position at the time to take advantage of that situation, we should have been able to issue our capital successfully and with great advantage to the company. Things, however, changed rapidly, and when we were ready the markets were less favourable- so much less favourable, indeed, that the directors did not deem it an opportune moment to place the shares upon the maket.

div.head: Army and Navy.
div.p: London, December 10. As has been already intimated in these notes, Colonel R. ©. Cox will vacate the com- mand of the 2nd Battalion Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, Alexandria, on the 26th prox. on completion of his four years at its head. Co- lonel Cox got his first commission iy the old 27th Inniskillings in June, 1879, got his com- pany in 1887 and majority in 1898. He served with the Ist Battalion in the South African war, and commanded it for the last two years of the stuggle with much ability in the fighting in the Transvaal, Orange River Colony and Cape Colony (mentioned in despatchesm brevet Lieutenant Colonelcy, Queen's medal with five clasps)

Major H.O.D. Hickman, second in command of the 1st Battalion, Crete, has been selected for the command of the 2nd Battalion, the step going to him in the usual course, he being the senior major of both battalions. Major Hickman is a very smart and popular officer and a staff college man as well. HE has spent since Janurary 1890 in the Inneskillings, and prior to that he was nine years in the Green Howards. He was attached to the Egyptian Army from 1885 to 1889, a portion of which time he was Assissant Military Scretary to the Sirdar so that his previous Egyptian service will be in his favour when he goes to the head of the 2nd Battalion. He served in the Nile Expedition, 1884-85 (medal with clasp,star); Soudan campaign, 1888, including the action Gemaizah (clasp, th class Medjidie); and the South African war 1901-02, inclusive of the actions of Belfast and Lydenburgh and the operations in Cape Colony, Natal, and the Transvaal (Queen's medal with two clasps).

div.head: Delegation Municipale
div.p: La Delegation s'est reunie le 17 decembre 1907 a 4 h. et ½ p.m. sous la presidence de S.E. Schiess Pacha. Etaient Ppresents M.M. Escoffier, Masour Bey Youssef, Ralli, Dr. Valensin et G. Zervudachi, membres, W.P. Chataway, administreur, I. Sedky Bey, secretaire general. Sur rapport des services la delgation adjuge a M. Mohamed Mohamed plus bas offrant, au prix total de L.E. 124,500 m. la fourniture de 150 bancs en bois avec pieda en fer courbe pour les jardins et squares de la villes.

Apres avoir pris connaissance d'une nouvelle note de L'Ingenieur en chef, relative aux avantages qu'il y aurait a recouvrir en briquettes d'asphalte la chaussee du pont route de la rue No.3, la delgation decide l'adoption de ce mode de pavage sur une superficie de 200 m.c. environ et autorise a cet effet une depense s'elevant dans sa totalite a L.E. 100.

div.head: Bulletin De La Bourse.
div.p: Notre marche, beacoup sans doute a cause de la situation generale et un peu a cause de 'approche des fetes correspondant aux inventaires, est tombe dans un etat de depression et d'accalmie completes. La place parait saturee de titres et les agents commencent a se fatiguer de sa passer les paquests les uns aux autres pour donner a la corbeille un semblant d'animation. Le fait est que la matinee a ete deplorable su double point de vue des transactions et des fluctuations. Tout le monde est vendeur et la contre- pagtie est presque introuvable. On ne sait quand prendra fin cette immobilite penible, mais on n'espere pas de relevemnt appreciable pour la fin de l'annee; on s'attend plutot a une accentuation de la faiblesse. Dans de telles conditions les affaires se limitent a des proportions insgnifiantes et la plupart des valeurs abordees s'inscrivent en nouvelle baisse.

Nautrellement les valeurs dirigeantes sont delaissees avec une legere depreciation: Ainsi l'Agricole flechit de 7 25/32 a 7 ¾, la National Bank de 20 1/16 a 2 la Daira de 12 ¾ a 12 5/8 et L'obligation ancienne Credit Foncier de 284 ½ a 282 ½. Seule de cette categorie, la Delta Light, a la faveur d'une demande, reprend de 9 9/16 a 9 5/8.
